question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned more about the complexity behind the US Healthcare system, especially how it is more than just the patient and doctor. Many other entities are necessary to facilitate healthcare, like government institutes, NGOs, payers, and more. 
2. I developed skills in working with groups, especially the psychology and techniques of collaboration. This was done through several lectures as well as interactive group activities. 
3. I also learned new methods for communicating information effectively, especially in legislative settings, by writing a health policy brief.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. how the US health system works
2. how to write a policy brief
3. health systems in other countries and what the US can learn from them

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I examined historical and present cases involving patient activism and advocacy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to communicate effectively in small group settings.
2. I learned how to have an active voice in writing.
3. I learned about the way that patients have worked to advocate for themselves, and what the average person can do to help.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to "descend the ladder of abstraction". In other words, this course taught me how to efficiently communicate discussion questions and scientific content surrounding medical issues to a general audience. Asking clear questions and giving context to ideas is so important in any discussion that the general audience, or in this case, patients, can enable the integration of their stories and ideas into discussions. I learned about the nuances of healthcare and clinical trials, as well as FDA approvals, rare disease advocacy, and how different diseases carry shifting narratives about the nature of those with the disease.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how patients came together and advocated for themselves, how disease is interpreted by different people, and how medicine is complex in that it involves every facet of humanity in a high stakes environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Angrist very quickly graded assignments and was incredibly helpful in providing feedback on every piece of writing we submitted. I definitely appreciated the system for discussion questions (with drops allowed for a set number) which helped to make sure I was actively engaged with the readings in which I had the time/capacity to be engaged with without making excuses and rushing through assignments.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Class was dedicated to discussion which meant that we would need to read the material beforehand in order to participate. The discussions were interesting, so it pushed me to do the readings, even though they could sometimes be laborious. The content was interesting as well. My favorite parts of this course were the guest speakers, the documentary we watched, and when we went to the library. Learning through something other than reading was very beneficial.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Angrist pushed me to write solid, concise discussion questions, which I appreciate so much. Instead of accepting my poor questions, he gave incredible feedback to craft my question-writing skills. I love how the classes were discussions about homework readings. The readings chosen were always interesting, and I came to appreciate the structure of medical journal articles, blog posts, and research summaries. I most of all am grateful for how Dr. Angrist gave such comprehensive feedback on our essays. I realized how to better tell a story.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was very clear in the way he graded work and formatted class. The clear and thorough syllabus and organization made the class as low stress as possible.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was intellectually stimulating in that we learned very relevant cases of patient activism that may not have been presented in the same way in different academic settings.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I did not think that I would learn as much as I did. We covered so much content and I feel like I gained a new perspective and appreciation for patients. Sometimes it felt as though the discussions could drag on, but because we were reading high level things, I'm not sure how that could be fixed. Overall, it was fun class, and I value the knowledge and friendships gained.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The guest speakers made this course very stimulating, as did the variety of assigned readings.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Every week, I learned about an entirely new facet of life, medicine, and disease. I could not have even imagined a class of this format. I felt like it broadened my horizons, and forced me to investigate complicated ideas and structures in very approachable ways. Anybody could take this class and enjoy it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Angrist is very kind and truly does want you to succeed. The content of the class is very engaging. Listen to his feedback on your writing, and put in effort to understand the common themes of the class.

response_text: I developed an efficient way to interact with text, analyze the society we live, and critically think about possible solutions to the inequities in American health.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about America's healthcare and the inequalities that arise under our current system. One of our main subjects was the social determinants of health, which explains the relationship between healthcare and public health. We most recently discussed maternal healthcare and race. A favorite topic of mine was when we explored photography and how it conveys health.

response_text: I explored ways of analyzing media through a different perspective than I had it explained to me in the past. I learned more about the American healthcare system as a whole, the policies that maintain and fuel social disparities, and the ways in which those disparities can and need to be addressed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

1. Skills about critically analyzing policies related to health.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I learned the importance of opening up our interpretation of what it means to be healthy. Health is determined by so many factors: our built environment, as shown by our visit to Hayti, structural and individual racism, policies, corruption in Big Food policy-making, corporation-funded research (Tobacco industry), gender norms (the villainization of single black mothers using WIC), and so much more. I learned to consider articles and stories from a humanities perspective, looking at healthcare from a lens of personal narratives. The narratives surrounding issues and history can greatly shape policy and how we interpret the healthcare system. Listening to the voices of community members is essential for cultivating healthy communities. Art can serve communities beyond aesthetics. Art can serve as an avenue of self-expression and direct community betterment. Diction can greatly influence how one's life is displayed. For instance, grief can be a better avenue for addressing systemic racism than guilt. Storytelling and photography can truly highlight the realities of this country's inequalities. I never would have understood the extent to which American gynecology was founded by taking advantage of black female bodies. From biological racism to bioethics and power structures, this class opened my eyes to the ways in which our society can shape our health and perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was introduced to many topics I had never been exposed to before, specially because this class was focused on the American healthcare system. I learned how to look at different sources, and how to differentiate which ones are reliable and peer-reviewed. I learned how to analyse texts and paragraphs in depth by breaking the analysis into five parts. I wrote my first Op-Ed essay. I learned how to approach things from a different lens because certain texts required looking at from a different perspective to understand the situation. My vocabulary expanded greatly because of the extensive reading, I was exposed to many new words that I am integrating in my writings for this class and my other classes as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned about the history of health policies in America and if they were successful as well as the social determinants of health in great depth.
2) A skill I developed was being able to read really long and dense readings in an efficient way and really understand what the author was trying to say
3) A way of thinking I learned is that things are always very complex and so there is never a "yes or no" answer to a question, especially regarding health policy outcomes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussion based learning of the course was great. I would continue with the double entry journals, as they were a great way to ensure I was actively reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the structure of this class because it is a comfortable, enjoyable conversation about the reading previously assigned. We also often thought of our own conversation questions and singled out passages that were important to us, which elevates it from just basic conversation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I believe that the open discussion based element of the class truly helped facilitate learning because it made everything feel like a very open and collaborative environment which helped to make learning easier.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Callahan did an incredible job guiding class discussions, encouraging healthy disagreements and conversations, and generally making the content very engaging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed both the class content and the way that the class was organized. I liked how we spent class time discussing what we had read about, and that we were consistently learning new things.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having such a heavy discussion based class was an integral part of my learning because it allowed me to hear other perspectives from my peers. However, we were still able to say on topic, as well as delve deeper into many topics, through Dr. Callahan’s guidance in our class discussions. Furthermore, having the discussions being led by our own thoughts helped maintain our engagement and interest throughout the semester, so it is a format I would highly recommend for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussions in class were very helpful as we heard each others' opinions. I also liked how I was able to really learn about the Hayti community through the field trip. Finally, I liked how we looked at social determinants of health through many different ways, such as readings, discussions, art, novels, etc.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Callahan created a space in the classroom that encouraged novel ideas from students. By creating a discussion-based course, the different interpretations of homework texts by respective students could be explored during respectful class debates. I honestly loved the entire structure of this course. The group infographic project was fun, our visit to Hayti was eye-opening and engaging, and the voice threads and double-entry journals invited us to bring our thoughts and experiences into the interpretations of class content. Dr. Callahan is a fair grader, a clear instructor, and gives great feedback on assignments.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Callahan was great at breaking down big assignments/ readings into pieces to help simplify and understand the prominent components. She was great at helping us establish our routine by assigning the weekly double-entry journals that help organise our thoughts and help us rethink what we read. In addition, she provided us with adequate knowledge about resources and how to recognise whether or not they should be used which I will definitely keep using in my future writings, papers, and classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was very small, only 12 people after drop-add. This made the in class discussions seem more relaxed and personal. I think being able to revise our assignments for a better grade from Dr. Callahan's feedback was a really great thing and should be kept in the future.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Dr. Callahan's questions and discussion topics made the class really stimulating; I always left feeling like I had thought about important and substantial topics, ones that I will likely think about in the future.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because it encouraged deep thought and contribution to an important discussion in the US.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Lively group discussions helped make the class very stimulating and exciting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We explored factors of healthcare without ever talking about healthcare itself, and I really found the policy and literature approach to be helpful in challenging my expectations of what content this class covers.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Because it was a small class, I felt like I needed to contribute to the conversation. It was nice hearing everyone's unique view, even if I didn't agree. I liked the consistent questions being brought up by our instructor as well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings and class discussions forced me to think much deeper beyond a surface level understanding and form connections between my existing knowledge and new information. This allowed me to gain a much nuanced understanding of the social determinants of health and the overall systems of power in our lives. Furthermore, looking at the interaction between things like policy, cultural attitudes, and media gave it an interdisciplinary aspect I highly enjoyed.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was stimulating because I got to hear about many different opinions around health and health policy. And in the meantime, I was thinking about what I thought about them. I thought that these interactions of opinions were really helpful. In addition, a lot of times health would be discussed in terms of the science of medicine. But in this class, we looked at other factors that can also significantly impact health.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class's content was very stimulating, particularly as we began to read first-hand accounts of people's experiences, and critiques of policy.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was interesting because I never studied anything about the healthcare system in the United States. it was nice to be introduced to such a different world because my brain was split and comparing the healthcare system and healthcare regulation to where I am from. I was interested in each of the policies that we looked at, and specially about how we studied women and how they are undermined in many cases. As a class filled with girls, I felt comfortable discussing such topics, and it was nice to see everyone's take and ideas on each of the policies.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was very debate heavy and I got to hear the different views of all my classmates on the same topic so it provoked new ways of thinking about it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great class! Not a heavy workload and the topics covered are incredibly interesting and relevant to today. Dr. Callahan is the sweetest!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class is great, and mostly because Dr. Callahan is very kind, intelligent, and stimulating. The workload was reasonable, and if you are interested in public health / human rights it is a great course to start with.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Even if you do not know anything about healthcare or policy, still take this course. The instructor is very accommodating and helpful.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class was incredibly refreshing, offering a unique approach to a topic that affects all of our lives- the social (and other) determinants of health. Show up for class prepared (the readings are not too challenging) and put in effort in class discussion- Dr. Callahan is a fantastic professor and really shows that she cares for her students.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are interested in health policies, and how the government influences health, but don't want to just listen to lectures, then this class is for you. Be prepared for a lot of reading and the expectation to participate in class discussions. You will be able to learn a lot as long as you apply yourself.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this class to anyone interested in health or health policy because it allows you to look at the field through many different lenses, ranging from bias in healthcare systems to social factors and biopolitics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say this is a good course if you want to learn more about social determinants of health/health policy. The class definitely touched on a variety of aspects around those topics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is amazing. I highly recommend taking it to understand how environmental factors and policies affect our health. Environmental factors like racism especially are important for understanding inequalities in all aspects of the healthcare system. This class is great for teaching critical thinking skills and considering the definition of health in a new light.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: To a student who is considering taking this class in the future, I would say that be ready to be introduced to new ideas and facts that are shocking about the world that we live in. The biopolitics of the world and how the social determinants of health truly impact and connect to everything. Be ready to ponder the question of healthcare and biases, and be ready to read a lot. The class requires a lot of thinking and analysing texts that are deep and sometimes confusing, but it is a different experience to learn about the healthcare system and some policies in depth.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class if you are interested in the medical or healthcare field at all. Also don't take this class if you are very shy and won't be able to participate in class discussions even though you want to.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about the social determinants of health. Reading all the policies improved my critical reading skills and ability to analyze text. The seminar style of the class also improved my confidence in public speaking.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to develop convincing arguments through insights derived from textual analysis and close reading as well as strong writing skills overall. I also learned how to analyze and interpret pictures and film media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Our class discussed various topics regarding public health in the United States. Some of which included urban renewal of various methods, the Affordable Care Act, and we analyzed photography collections to see how individuals live on the flip-side of major tourism, such as Niagara Falls and Disney World.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the social determinants of health, health policy, health advocacy, and various issues in U.S. healthcare and society. I developed skills in data imaging, group work, and crafting efficient arguements.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Data application and presentation, textual analysis skills (especially with visual media), contributing to class discussions based on class readings

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained experience thinking about American Healthcare from an "upstream" persepctive. We looked at a variety of policies, cultural texts, and films during class. We learned how to analyze data and write responses to said texts and media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I learned how to analyse and read texts effectively
- Representing data effectively 
- Looking into issues and identifying potential solutions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned how to analyze diverse forms of media, the processes behind the development and dissemination of policy, and the importance of diverse viewpoints in copleting one's understanding of a social issue.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to actively engage in a seminar style class, how to write effectively on prevalent social issues, how to learn from other’s inputs and opinions from class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think one of the main things I developed by taking this course was increasing my ability to have conversations about texts; I really appreciate having a structure where I know what exactly is going to be discussed in class and what topics I can brush up on to be more prepared. I think the ways the conversations were structured really helped understanding the text and topics being discussed. I also really appreciated the textual analysis assignment structure because it allowed me to know exactly what I had to do and when. I also appreciated the versatility of the course and the wide range of topics and discussions we had in this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to better analyze texts that were more difficult to understand. Longer texts also helped me develop the skill of careful skimming. Through discussions, the reader response journals, and the annotations, I was able to refine my skills of comprehending the meaning, understanding the significance within the work, and applying what I learned to outside topics. 
2. Health policies were a topic I was not previously educated on. I learned about the process to policy implication and how each policy differed in every state. 
3. I also developed the skill of writing concisely and quickly without an excess of words.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Callahan's guiding questions during discussion proved very helpful. I also liked how we followed the syllabus very consistently.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the format of in-class discussions because it was flexible to everyone's level of comfort in speaking and gave us time to formulate thoughts and digest ideas without feeling the pressure of having to answer preemptively.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Most of the time, we opened up class for discussion on the topics we were focusing on. Other times, we worked in small groups to come up with plans such as the most effective method of urban renewal. Finally, we completed a data story presentation on trends regarding Medicaid, a textual analysis, and an annotated bibliography on a research question of our choosing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The reader response was a weekly response on the readings that we engaged in during class. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated how Dr. Callahan guided the class with interesting questions and thoughtful input. I felt that she listened to each response and didn't expect one "right" answer. I think the discussions flow pretty well and I learn a lot from them. I like the different perspectives people offer. I also really enjoyed the field trip we went on and hearing from the speakers. It helped connect our readings with more concrete real life stories.
